title: LIVE: AFR Energy Summit Day 2 Macquarie blames policy uncertainty
text:
The chief executive of French-owned energy group Engie has warned that an increasing amount of ''ad-hoc'' intervention by the Federal Government is a bad sign for investors sizing up potential energy investments in Australia.

Augustin Honorat said capital would flow into countries where there is a stable policy environment and much more certainty is needed in Australia.

He declined to be specific about which of the ''ad-hoc interventions'' were the most problematic, but warned that electricity customers would end up paying for those projects in higher energy bills.

"These will be locked into customers bills for decades and may not actually satisfy their needs into the future,'' Mr Honorat said.

He declined to say if one of those ad-hoc interventions was the Snowy Hydro 2.0 project."I'm not pointing at any specific intervention''.

Engie operates the Pelican Point gas-fired power station in Adelaide and in 2017 shut down the Hazelwood coal-fired power station in Victoria, which removed about one quarter of that state's baseload supply.

The Hazelwood shutdown has been part of a global shift by Engie away from coal and into renewable energy projects.

He said Engie had invested $5 billion into Australia in the past few years and wanted to keep investing, but market interventions by government were making it more fraught."

We want to continue to do that but we need to have that stable framework,'' he said.

He said risks around technology shifts in the energy sector were best handled by the private operators.

"Technology risks should be handled by the private sector''.
description: As a large investor in renewables, Macquarie Bank says policy uncertainty, not a lack of capital investment, was the main issue facing the transition to a carbon economy. Follow the live blog for more.
